description: From earlier blurre, probably an alteration of blear, from Middle English bleren, from Old English blerian. Compare Scots blore, bloar (“to blur, cover with blots”). More at blear.

adjectives.description: blur (comparative more blur, superlative most blur)

entries.meaning: (Malaysia, Singapore, informal) In a state of doubt or confusion.
Something that appears hazy or indistinct
examples: The surroundings went by in a blur.
[…] with her raillyng sette a great blurre on myne honesty

verbs.description: blur (third-person singular simple present blurs, present participle blurring, simple past and past participle blurred)

entries.meaning: To make indistinct or hazy, to obscure or dim.
examples: to blur a photograph by moving the camera while taking it
to blur a manuscript by handling it while damp

entries.meaning: To cause imperfection of vision in; to dim; to darken.
examples: His eyes are blurred with the lightning's glare.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To sully; to stain; to blemish, as reputation.
examples: Sarcasms may eclipse thine own, / But cannot blur my lost renown.

entries.meaning: (graphical user interface, transitive) To transfer the input focus away from.
examples: Then give this box focus to blur the first one:  […]
